title: January 2009 Licensure Paper Three
description: NCK January 2009 Paper Three Licensure Examination covering Community Health Nursing, Mental Health & Midwifery. Note: Part III was not available in the source archive.

questions.question: Cross immunity can be defined as:

options.text: The immunity level that is present in a population group.
Long term and sometimes life-long resistance that is acquired either naturally or artificially.
Short-term resistance that is acquired either naturally or artificially.
A situation in which a personâ€™s immunity to one agent provides immunity to another related agent.

questions.explanation: Cross immunity occurs when an immune response to one pathogen (e.g., Cowpox) provides protection against a different but antigenically related pathogen (e.g., Smallpox).
questions.hint: Think about how exposure to one thing protects against a 'related' thing.

questions.question: Ergonomic factors include:

options.text: The responses and behavior that workers exhibit on the job.
Living organism found in the work environment.
All the interactions between the worker, the demands of the job, the work setting and the environment.
Structural elements of the workplace that influence worker health and productivity.

questions.explanation: Ergonomics (human factors) is the scientific discipline concerned with the understanding of interactions among humans and other elements of a system to optimize well-being and performance.
questions.hint: It involves the 'interaction' between the human and the work system.

questions.question: A child growing within normal developmental milestones will be able to have good head control at the age of:
questions.explanation: An infant typically achieves full head control (no head lag) by 3-4 months. By 6 months, head control is well established.
questions.hint: This is one of the earliest motor milestones.

questions.question: Campylobacter jejuni:

options.text: Is isolated less frequently from infants and young adults.
Grows best in an environment of less oxygen than the amount in the atmosphere.

questions.explanation: Campylobacter jejuni is microaerophilic, meaning it requires reduced oxygen levels (about 5%) to grow compared to atmospheric levels (21%).
questions.hint: It likes 'micro' (small) amounts of air.

questions.question: The clinical picture of trachoma in stage four would be:
questions.explanation: Stage IV (Trachomatous Trichiasis) involves severe scarring causing the inturning of eyelashes (Trichiasis) and eyelids (Entropion).
questions.hint: This is the advanced stage where eyelashes turn inward.

questions.question: Familiarization assessment as a type of community needs assessment involves:

options.text: The researcher focusing on single problem and studies the community in terms of that problem.
Examining a single facet of community life.
An in-depth survey of the entire community.
Studying data already available in the community and gathering a certain amount of first hand data.

questions.explanation: Familiarization (or 'Windshield Survey') involves reviewing existing records and observing the community to get a general overview.
questions.hint: It is about getting 'familiar' with what is already known.

questions.question: The direct health effects of ozone depletion include:

options.text: Increased risk for skin cancer and breast cancer.
Increased risk of skin cancer and cataracts.
Increased risks of cataracts and exposure to vector borne diseases.
Increased population exposure to vector borne diseases and increased risk for skin cancer and cataracts.

questions.explanation: Ozone depletion leads to increased UV radiation (skin cancer, cataracts) and potential climate changes affecting vectors.
questions.hint: Choose the option that covers both the UV effects and the environmental vector changes.

questions.question: The vaccine that is heat stable, not destroyed rapidly at room temperature, and remains active for at least 6 weeks at 37 degrees C is:
questions.explanation: Tetanus Toxoid (TT) is one of the most heat-stable vaccines. Measles and BCG are very heat sensitive.
questions.hint: This vaccine is often given to pregnant women and is very robust.

questions.question: The number of deaths from all causes during a given year divided by the population estimated at midyear times a thousand is referred to as the:
questions.explanation: This is the standard definition of Crude Death Rate (CDR). It is 'crude' because it doesn't account for age or cause.
questions.hint: It is a general 'crude' measure of mortality.

questions.question: In the treatment of tuberculosis, the 'DOTS' approach refers to:

options.text: Patient getting TB treatment as close to home as possible.
Patient adheres to treatment during the intensive phase only.
Directly observed treatment with weekly monitoring.
Patient takes every drug dosage under supervision during the intensive phase.

questions.explanation: DOTS ensures the patient swallows the medication under the direct supervision of a health worker, especially during the intensive phase.
questions.hint: Think about what 'Directly Observed' means practically.

questions.question: The following is an adverse effect of Nevirapine:
questions.explanation: Major adverse effects of Nevirapine (NVP) are severe skin rashes and hepatotoxicity (liver damage).
questions.hint: NVP affects the liver.

questions.question: When health care is geographically, financially and culturally within reach of the entire community, the service is said to be:
questions.explanation: Accessibility encompasses geographical reach, financial affordability, and cultural acceptability.
questions.hint: It starts with 'A' and means you can get to it in all ways.

questions.question: The habit disorders you can discover while assessing the psychological aspect of school children include:
questions.explanation: Habit disorders include repetitive behaviors like thumb sucking and enuresis (bedwetting). Delusions/hallucinations are psychotic.
questions.hint: Look for common childhood habits, not severe mental illnesses.

questions.question: In a community, evidence of continuity of quality health care includes:

options.text: Lower all-cause mortality, better access to care.
Better access to care, increased uptake of disease-focused preventive care.
Lower all-cause mortality, increased satisfaction with services.
Better access to care, increased satisfaction with services.

questions.explanation: Continuity of care is linked to better health outcomes (lower mortality) and higher patient satisfaction.
questions.hint: It leads to better survival and happier patients.

questions.question: The purpose of a screening test is to:

options.text: Collect data for a mass campaign.
Check whether a population is at risk of a disease.
Detect person with risk factors or subclinical disease.

questions.explanation: Screening is not diagnostic; it identifies apparently healthy individuals who may have risk factors or subclinical disease.
questions.hint: Screening finds the 'hidden' cases before they are diagnosed.

questions.question: One of the targets for improved maternal health under the Millennium Development Goals (MDG) is to reduce by:
questions.explanation: MDG Goal 5 Target 5.A was to reduce the maternal mortality ratio by three quarters (75%).
questions.hint: The goal was 75% reduction.

questions.question: An assessment of family health will be most accurate if it incorporates the following guidelines:

options.text: Focusing on the family as a total unit, collection of data once.
Collecting of data once, exercising professional judgment.
Focusing on the family as a total unit, combining quantitative and qualitative data.
Using quantitative data, exercising professional judgment.

questions.explanation: Accurate assessment requires a holistic view (family as a unit) and mixed methods (quantitative and qualitative data).
questions.hint: Look for the most 'holistic' option.

questions.question: A major cause of 'missed opportunity' in the immunization programme is:

options.text: Use of vaccines that have lost potency.
High rates of drop outs among target group.

questions.explanation: A missed opportunity is when a client is present but doesn't get the vaccine. Stock outs are a major cause of this.
questions.hint: You can't give the vaccine if it isn't there.

questions.question: The methods commonly used in Africa to measure population include:
questions.explanation: Due to incomplete civil registration, African countries rely heavily on Census and surveys like DHS.
questions.hint: Civil registration is often incomplete in developing nations.

questions.question: Non-organic growth failure in a child may be attributed to:

options.text: Altered physiology due to improper feeding.
A poor mother-child bond of attachment.

questions.explanation: Non-organic failure to thrive is caused by psychosocial factors, such as lack of emotional bonding or maternal deprivation.
questions.hint: 'Non-organic' means not physical/biological.

questions.question: Which of the following are factors that influence the acceptance and continuation of family planning? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Factors include education, religion, culture, cost, side effects, and partner support.
questions.hint: Think about social, economic, and personal factors.

questions.question: Which of the following are sources of information for epidemiological studies? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Sources include census, vital stats, hospital records, and disease notification.
questions.hint: Epidemiology relies on official data.

questions.question: Match the disease with its causative organism:
questions.explanation: Visceral Leishmaniasis -> Leishmania donovani; Elephantiasis -> Wuchereria bancrofti; Cholera -> Vibrio cholerae; Plague -> Yersinia pestis.
questions.hint: Look for the scientific name that sounds like the disease.

questions.question: Arrange the steps of the problem-solving process in sequential order:
questions.explanation: The process is: Identify -> Analyze -> Generate -> Select -> Implement -> Evaluate.
questions.hint: You must define the problem before you can fix it.

questions.question: Match the disaster management element with its definition:

pairs.right: Activities to provide permanent protection (e.g., dams)
Measures to minimize destructive effects of hazards

questions.explanation: Prevention stops the disaster from happening. Mitigation reduces the damage if it does happen.
questions.hint: Prevention = stop it. Mitigation = lessen impact.
